abstract: A French artist brings her intensely autobiographical work to an uptown hotel.
snippet: A French artist brings her intensely autobiographical work to an uptown hotel.
lead_paragraph: Before boarding a flight from Paris this week, Sophie Calle stuffed her suitcase with a selection of choice possessions that hold personal significance, including one red and one white wedding dress, a wig, a framed portrait of Freud, a sprawled stuffed cat and an issue of TeleStar with Peter Falk on the cover, circa 1986. Upon arrival in New York, the French artist, best known for her intensely autobiographical work, proceeded to unpack these items at the Lowell Hotel where she has taken over a suite for "Room," an installation commissioned by French Institute Alliance Française as part of Crossing the Line, an annual festival of contemporary art. Calle's inventory also includes a few specialty items she sourced locally, like a burnt mattress, a baby stroller and a Remington Noiseless Portable typewriter. The artist herself will also appear from time to time over the show's run.

headline.main: The Suite Life | Sophie Calle at the Lowell Hotel
